title: In Carpenter v. United States, will the Supreme Court rule that investigators' warrantless use of Timothy Carpenter's cellphone records was unconstitutional?

Under Supreme court case law information doesn't have to be excluded if it was according to the law, even if the law was found later to be unconstitutional.  In other words,  the Supreme Court could reverse, and carpenter still go to jail.  BTW case law is absolutely clear:  the law as written is on the side of the US. At the heart of the matter is that in the digital age we 'voluntarily' (does anyone read those disclosure forms we sign) give away information to third parties.   Facebook.  Mobile Companies.  Apps of all colors and sizes.  The Government can seize that information by requesting it from those companies.   The courts reasoning previously was that if you voluntarily gave someone information - you don't have an expectation of privacy.  So.  The court clearly needs to do something about the Miller and Smith rulings.  The only real question is - can they carve out an exception, and will they do so in time.  This case was argued in November - the fact that they hve not issued an opinion yet speaks to the huge scope of this issue and the size of the problem.  Problems with the wording: 1.  Is the question (really) will his conviction be overturned?
2.  Is the question - was the previous action be found unconstitutional
3.  Or will the Justices find that while the action was done correctly, under previous law, the standard is now to be changed. 
4.  Will they do it in time?  So,  I believe 1.  They will find the previous actions were done in accordance with the law. 
2.  They will enumerate a new law regarding third party disclosures. 
3.  I think the court will eventually uphold his conviction. 
4.  I think a decision will happen in this term.  But I have time to change if it gets closer to the end of term. http://www.scotusblog.com/2017/11/argument-preview-justices-return-cellphones-fourth-amendment/

Re-iterating my prediction. Use of cellphone location-data records to track suspects was used in a very similar manner to help identify the Austin-area bomber.  https://www.washingtonpost.com/world/national-security/surveillance-footage-cellphone-data-led-to-takedown-of-austin-bomber-officials-say/2018/03/21/04a8a91e-2d42-11e8-b0b0-f706877db618_story.html?utm_term=.2369dd1896ea

The main issue in this case is determining whether or not cell-site records are subject to 4th Amendment restrictions. The current law has characterized call-detail records as “non-communication content” thereby not subject to the 4th Amendment. The only other case where a number of exceptions were raised was the Jones decision where the mitigating factors were attributed to GPS-data and “long term” tracking; neither of those factors apply to the Carpenter case since it is based on cell-site data which is less accurate than GPS and the historical tracking does not fall as “long term”.

There was no good reason not to seek a warrant. This is about protecting the Bill of Rights! And punishing sloppy police work. Or it should be.

The Court will likely focus on the fact that the data does not contain personnal correspondance, but only tracks the individual, which is a necessity for cell phone operation.  Moreover, the individual could have shut down his cell phone and not be tracked, so he had the capacity to ensure his own privacy.

On the basis of a prosecutor’s unsworn request, the government obtained cell phone location information from multiple cell providers of a single person over an 127 day period.  In oral arguments the government argued that it would not matter if the type of information requested could be very precise nor that the information requested could be over periods longer than 127 days, all that is irrelevant, according to the government’s argument, because the demand for the information was [to] a third-party, and because Congress explicitly authorized a warrantless form of cell phone data search.  The justices were very focused on and hostile to that argument.   So why is it not 100% “yes”?  To my surprise the Court has other precedents authorizing searching the personal effects of targets where those effects are held by third-parties and supported by subpoena.  These form part of the basis of the government’s argument, and will present a problem for the Court in how to strike down warrantless searches of cell records without undoing warrantless searches of bank records and other sensitive information held by third parties.
Knowing how critical these records are to current law enforcement, the judges will invent some rationalization.
The court has already begun to view cellphones as a more and more important source of information, and a place where information is kept. This process will continue with this ruling
Search warrants can be obtained from a court after demonstrating probable cause.

I don't think they will rule it unconstitutional.  This is meta data and this type of data whether it is your location data, viewing (TV) habits or browsing searches is routinely sold without your consent currently.
This 'phone location record' is metadata = there is no expectation of privacy; SCOTUS has already ruled on this in other FBI/Intelligence Community cases.
Conservative court will see this as opportunity to rule on need of warrants to collect evidence.
If records were to be found in a trash can, why would that be wrong?

The oral argument suggests the justices are leaning in this direction, which would be consistent with U.S. v. Jones (tracker device on car) and Riley v. California (warrant for cell phone).

After reading the oral argument. This case may NOT go the usual 5-4 way and Justice Kennedy may  NOT be the deciding vote. 
The Petitioner's argument (Carpenter) was that cell phone tower data was collected over the course of 127 days is "long term surveillance", which require a warrant. The Government's position was that they did obtain a Court Order, which is allowed in the Stored Communication Act (boy-oh-boy, Congress needs to do something about that SCA law because it is clearly obsolete). Justice Kennedy: would not see the difference between 1 day or 127 days as relevant, and that there was court supervision over law enforcement provided by the SCA when law enforcement obtained a Court Order to subpoena the cell phone towers' data.  It is unclear that Justice Kennedy would agree that the data should be used as part of the prosecution or not. He may incline to see data used to narrow down the field of suspects, but not as evidence by itself to convict.  Justice Alito & Gorsuch: they are on the property right angle. If they found that Carpenter has property right to his cell phone location record (likely they would), then the Fourth Amendment requires a warrant and supersedes SCA. Justice Kennedy may not agree on this though. He wondered why Congress provides both means: a Court Order and a Warrant, so if Warrant is always required then is there a use for a Court Order. Justice Kagan and Sotomayor: they are afraid and very afraid of the precision of the technology. If placing a GPS on a car without a warrant is unconstitutional, then using cellphone location data would be unconstitutional as well, since its tracking ability has improved and will continue to improve. Without mentioning it, but clearly in the mind of the Justices, Amazon and Google's ability, with Alexa-like devices, would be able to record conversations in bedrooms, where the consumers expect total privacy. Would law enforcement be able to require Amazon to disclose whatever Alexa collected and transmitted to the cloud?  Justice Breyer: he is sympathetic to the Petitioner.  So far, I think it is likely they would decide for Carpenter.

See Essentially 702 focuses on the ability to collect foreign intelligence information from foreign persons who themselves are in foreign places, using U.S. infrastructure. That last part is what makes 702 so special: it attempts to regulate the collection and processing of foreign intelligence when it is on U.S. infrastructure, so that we can fully attempt to protect U.S. persons’ privacy. That is all the authority does, no more no less. But while the explanation of what the law is intended to do may appear simple, with no implications for American civil liberties, in practice separating the communications of legitimate foreign intelligence targets from U.S. persons is difficult and incidental collection occurs – leading some to cry foul. Incidental collection is probably one of the most misunderstood terms on the planet. To many people when they hear the term, it conjures up the idea that when you are intending to collect one communication, you somehow got a second, another. That is not what it means. What it means is that because every communication has at least two ends, if you are focused on one end of that then you are necessarily going to incidentally collect both ends. And that communication is therefore thought to be the property of two or more people. That second person is the incidental collection. Some have demanded that the NSA immediately remove and report all incidentally collected communications belonging to a U.S. person, but doing so has its challenges
Most of the time you have no idea who that second person is, as you are targeting the person of interest. You really don’t know his or her status until you look at the communication, and even then, it is very seldom that you know what his or her citizenship is or what their proclivities are. In order to understand that, you have to spend some time and attention thinking about them. That is the conundrum here. When asked, does the intelligence community know how many times they incidentally collect a U.S. person, the general answer is no, because in order to know that, you would have to focus attention on that second person – in many cases, with no just cause. They have not done anything to deserve the attention of the U.S. intelligence community. To minimize the possibility of picking up the inadvertent collection of U.S. person communications, the NSA decided in May that it would end what is known as “about” collection. Currently, the decision is merely a policy choice on the part of the NSA, but some have suggested that the change should be codified in a reauthorized FISA 702 bill. But what is “about” collection and should it be codified?"

https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States_v._Jones_(2012)
https://www.oyez.org/cases/2011/10-1259 As pointed out by at least @JMR2017, United States v. Jones is illuminating. It was a similar question, and the Court had the same composition as today with the exception of Justice Gorsuch who has replaced Justice Scalia since then. Alito, Ginsburg, Breyer, Kagan, and Sotomayor thought back then that obtaining location information over a long period of time requires a warrant based on reasonable expectation of privacy. However, it's important to note that the Chief Justice, Kennedy, and Thomas didn't necessarily disagree with that view. From page 11 of the majority opinion (https://www.supremecourt.gov/opinions/11pdf/10-1259.pdf): "It may be that achieving the same result through electronic means, without an accompanying trespass, is an unconstitutional invasion of privacy, but the present case does not require us to answer that question." (Also quoted in the Wikipedia article.) The government's reasoning is basically that the location information in this case wasn't obtained in a search by government agents, it was third party information from the cell service company. They say that so far, third party information has been obtainable by subpoena even though it may reveal aspects about the subject's private life. The government also says that in the current scheme of things, there is a degree of protection w/r/t cell site information since a court order is required. But the government's attorney had a hard time in oral argument. It seems to me that a strong majority of the Court will view that location data over a long period of time is something that requires a warrant—whether it be obtained by planting a GPS device (Jones case) or by obtaining records from a cell service company (current case). Also, the fact that the same result could be achieved without a warrant by "tailing" a suspect 24/7 is a false analogy because his location _in the past_ can't be revealed even in that manner. I leave only 10 % for the possibility that the Court distinguishes this case from Jones because no literal search occurred and because no property intrusion occurred.

Shifting higher because the court seemed to be wrestling more with how to protect cellphone data than whether to. https://www.economist.com/news/united-states/21731880-carpenter-v-united-states-shows-they-are-unsure-about-how-do-so-supreme-courts

Agree with @Gibson on this case cc: @lsgold7  (US v. Jones) is illuminating -  Alito filed an opinion concurring in the judgment, in which Ginsburg, Breyer, and Kagan joined.   "But where uncertainty exists with respect to whether a certain period of GPS surveillance is long enough to constitute a Fourth Amendment search, the police may always seek a warrant."   Does the court in Carpenter have to draw a specific timeline for what is considered long term surveillance that would require a warrant?  I think it's possible to get more than a majority of Justices to require a warrant. I base this on how they voted in Jones but the difference here is the third party doctrine operating in this case as opposed to (Jones) the government attaching the GPS device on the property of the defendant (his car).  In this case,  can the government simply hide behind the curtain in the name of the 3rd party doctrine? What's at issue is a person's reasonable expectation of privacy even though here, we are talking about a person voluntarily carrying the surveillance device (their phones) on their own person. I don't think people have a choice in this digital age to not be tracked but how much and for how long seems to be the issue. Even if you turn off "location" on your smart phone, you can be tracked when you make a call or check your email, or open an app. Location can be tracked more precisely in an urban setting where there are numerous cell towers.  So what's a reasonable expectation of privacy?  The dragnet type searches where law enforcement gets a "cell tower dump" over weeks and months at a time without the specificity of a warrant surely seem unreasonable. It would seem the court could come down on the side of long term tracking is unreasonable without having to specify a time period.
As if the court has cared about this before.

and Breyer " no such thing in the law as location"
and Kennedy
"Well, frankly, if -- if we're going to talk about normal expectations and we have to make the judgment, it seems to me there's a much more normal expectation that businesses have your cell phone data. I think everybody, almost everybody, knows that. If I know it, everybody does. (Laughter.)"
and Breyer
"Since I'm seeing your argument, it -- it -- it starts with a place where I completely agree. The village snoop had a fallible memory and didn't follow people for 127 days. The electronic information is infallible. You can follow them forever. That's a big change. So, I agree that that change is there. It's there in many aspects of life, not just location. Now, on the other side of it is that probably, I'm not sure, but probably police and FBI and others, when they get word of white collar crime, money laundering, drugs, financing terrorism, we can go through the list, large numbers of cases, of important criminal cases, they don't have probable cause. They do have reasonable ground to think. And they start with bank records, with all kinds of financial information, purchases. So, if I accept your line, there's no such thing in the law as location. There is, but, I mean, people immediately say and why? And then, when they say why, we're going to have to say something like: X days, at least arbitrary, but X days, are very personal. It was given under circumstances where they didn't know they were giving it or they certainly didn't consent to it. And that is basically the reason. Maybe we throw a few other things in there to get an exception from Miller. That will be taken immediately to the lower courts, and eventually here, and people will say: Well, what about financial information, i.e., credit card purchases where the most intimate credit card purchases, wherever they are, are immediately records, and what about -- and they'll think of five others -- I can only think of one or two, but, believe me, the legal profession and those interested in this understand it very well. So where are we going? Is this the right line? How do we, in fact, write it? Not, you see, for location. I have less trouble with that. But where is it going? Can you say -- it's a very open question, but I'm very interested in your reactions." "unadministrable"
 says  Stephen G. Breyer

Based on oral arguments, it seems that a majority are supportive of privacy rights. To illustrate across the board concern, Gorsuch invokes John Adams to support privacy and Sotomayor referred to possible technological advances in the future. @Gibson offers insightful analysis.

https://ballotpedia.org/Carpenter_v._United_States?utm_source=Iterable&utm_medium=email&utm_campaign=DailyBrew
technological advancements have dramatically changed the privacy calculus."[2] Orin Kerr, the Fred C. Stevenson Research Professor at George Washington University, wrote regarding the case in The Washington Post that "it’s not an exaggeration to say that the future of surveillance law hinges on how the Supreme Court rules in the case.
information from the cell phone provided the FBI's basis to petition for judicial orders under the Stored Communications Act (hereafter, SCA) to obtain call and cell phone location data held by Carpenter's and Sanders' cellular service providers. The SCA did not require the government to show probable cause or to obtain a warrant in order to obtain the data.
In April of 2011, police arrested four men in connection with a string of armed robberies of stores in and around Detroit, Michigan. The stores were Radio Shacks and T-Mobile stores. During police questioning, one of the suspects confessed that the group had committed robberies of nine stores in Michigan and Ohio over a four-month period from December of 2010 to March of 2011. During these robberies, the suspect informed police than an additional 15 men, alternating across robberies, served in various support capacities such as serving as police lookouts and as getaway drivers. The suspect forfeited his cell phone to FBI authorities, who examined the phone's call records for additional information. In May and June of 2011, the FBI applied for three different judicial orders in order to obtain transactional records for 16 different phone numbers gleaned from the suspect's phone. The evidence the FBI sought was for records that "included '[a]ll subscriber information, toll records and call detail records including listed and unlisted numbers dialed or otherwise transmitted to and from [the] target telephones from December 1, 2010 to present[,]' as well as 'cell site information for the target telephones at call origination and at call termination for incoming and outgoing calls[.]'" The orders were granted pursuant to the Stored Communications Act (hereafter, SCA). Under the SCA, the government can mandate the disclosure of certain telephone or telecommuncations records if "specific and articulable facts show[] that there are reasonable grounds to believe that the contents of a wire or electronic communication, or the records or other information sought, are relevant and material to an ongoing criminal investigation.” Prior to a federal trial on various charges, the petitioners, Timothy Ivory Carpenter and Timothy Michael Sanders, moved to suppress the evidence obtained by police under the SCA-authorized judicial orders. The petitioners alleged that the cellphone records could only be obtained via a warrant issued by a judge and supported by a showing of probable cause. The trial judge, Judge Sean Cox of the United States District Court for the Eastern District of Michigan, denied the motion.[7]
Several of the court members appear to be moving in this direction. The facts in this case make the government's argument a bit of a stretch.

Katz v. United States defined Fourth Amendment protections of homes vs. open fields. In public, people are no longer entitled to such protection because eyewitnesses can track/report a person's whereabouts. If a person is in his/her home, then they are protected. However, in Hoffa vs. United States, the courts ruled that if a person in a private home broadcasts their location to 3rd party, this protection no longer applies. Basically, you can't have it both ways - once you involve a 3rd party, you forfeit 4th amendment protection since the government can simply ask the 3rd party. In Carpenter vs. United States, the government contends that all cell phone customers agree to share location data with the companies as a condition of service. As with Gotti, Carpenter can't refuse to be tracked by the cell phone company AND expect to be able to use his phone at the same time. I expect that the ruling will be upheld, but am allowing for a small possibility of judicial activism.
This will be a red line for all conservatives out there. Need and will receive a 5-4 decision.

This case lost in the Sixth Circuit court of appeals, because it reached the conclusion that the third-party doctrine applied, i.e. that law enforcement does not need a warrant for data residing with a third party - the wireless carriers. The argument on the other side (supported by the Brennan Center, the Electronic Frontier Foundation, Constitution Project, National Association of Criminal Defense Lawyers, and National Association of Federal Defenders) is that cell phone location data creates an unprecedented opportunity for law enforcement to reconstruct past movements with remarkable accuracy and reveals private social, political, and religious activities protected by the Constitution.  They argue that this data has such significant implications for freedom of speech and association that it demands a warrant supported by probable cause, no less than private papers in a desk drawer. There are precedents affirming that we should have reasonable expectations of privacy in many cases where the information is in the possession of a 3rd party:
-	Patients can expect privacy of their diagnostic test results, even when the hospital maintains the records (Ferguson v. City of Charleston)
-	Passengers can expect privacy of their luggage placed in an overhead bin despite the possibility of external inspection by others (Bond v. United States)
-	Hotel guests are entitled to constitutional protections even though they provide “implied or express permission” for third parties to access their rooms (Stoner v. California)
-	People have an expectation of privacy in email content, even if they use a third party service provider to transmit that email (United States v. Warshak) Thomas, Gorsuch and Alito will almost certainly reject the argument that cell phone location data deserves the protection of the fourth amendment - if the founding fathers had wanted this, they would have written something about cell phones in the constitution, right??? I haven't thought too hard about where Roberts will fall, because I think - as is often the case, decisions boil down to what Kennedy thinks.  Kennedy makes a big distinction between the fourth amendment affording you liberty, but NOT privacy.  He is a big proponent of constitutional liberty - protecting the individual from government interference in personal autonomy (See his lecture at the Aspen Institute).  I believe Kennedy will rule that warrantless use of cell phone location  records was unconstitutional.

Historical cell phone records are part of a class of information that is in a grey area with respect to right to privacy. Traditionally left wing politics have placed greater emphasis on protecting privacy, particularly in new technological areas. However for the past several decades left wing philosophy has emphasised financially protecting classes of disadvantaged people, over protecting individual disadvantaged people. An externality of this shift in philosophical reasoning is left wing politics is less willing to protect privacy, particularly in areas perceived to be domains of the well off - technology is one of these.

It is the owner of the record, not its subject, which must be subpoenaed if they don't give consent for a search.  People may feel funky about this, and probably should, but telephone records belong to the telephone company and not to any party to the calls.
My impression is that the court has been open to expected digital privacy protections based on the fourth amendment. For example ruling that phones are subject search warrants.

Concurring with the average of predictions, pending oral argument later this month. There are at least 4 Justices who agreed to take the case (meaning 4 ready to reverse the lower court's decision that it was constitutional.

To me there is a lot of uncertainty to how justices will apply law to modern technology. Although Gorusch is conservative, and conservatives are more often seen as "tough on crime", it seems his originalist interpretation ends him up as being sympathetic to the rights of the defenders in Fourth Amendment cases. [1] United States vs. Jones seems to be a popular citation in the forecasts. Putting a GPS onto someone's private property (car) to track them is one thing, but the collection of phone data from a cell provider under SCA seems valid. The information was clearly pertinent to the criminal case, the main consideration for being able to use the SCA: ...“specific and articulable facts showing that there are reasonable grounds to believe” that records at issue “are relevant and material to an ongoing criminal investigation”; the government does not need to show that there is probable cause to believe that a crime has been committed. [2] In addition, cell phone contracts in the modern era almost certainly require you to voluntarily give up cell tower usage/location as part of the phone contract, what with all the fine print. I can't think that the court will be able to take the defendant's claim seriously, that he did not voluntarily give up his cell tower communications away to a third party. Regardless of how one feels about the need to delineate between what scope of information being seized by government/investigative agents (I think there is a valid concern that privacy in the modern era can be easily eroded), I don't think the judges will be able to rule in favor of the defendant given existing laws. I am no legal expert though. [1] http://www.scotusblog.com/2017/03/gorsuch-fourth-amendment/
[2] http://www.scotusblog.com/2017/07/justices-return-cellphones-fourth-amendment-plain-english/ Writ of certiorari: http://www.scotusblog.com/wp-content/uploads/2016/10/16-402-cert-petition.pdf
Gorsuch will replace Scalia's vote in Jones

Unconstitutional? Certainly. But to say that the Supreme Court will rule that way is another matter entirely. The Supreme Court has been eroding privacy standards when it comes to warrant-less gathering of records of individuals for the last generation. To expect them to suddenly reverse course and come to the proper decision is a long-shot.
Pen registers are legal.  I think that the Supreme Court will rule that location data is not private
Unclear if the older judges can understand the implications of search and seizures on electronics.  Kennedy will be the swing vote as usual.

Upon reading the case filings and the decision of the Appeals Court, including the dissent, I do not anticipate SCOTUS to find a fourth amendment protection for the records of an individual stored with a business. My hedging is based on the recognition that ubiquitous data about our location and activities offers the government a form of passive general surveillance not imagined by the Framers. If some business put cameras at every intersection and used facial recognition to record our movements, would the government need a warrant to access this data?

The records belong to the phone company, not him; if the company voluntarily turned them over, he's out of luck.  My guess is this is in the same general category as CCTV footage of you driving your car like a bat out of hell away from the crime scene--the matter being examined by the police is not your property even if you have a starring role, nor do you have any derived right to control its use or distribution.  Besides, anybody who does anything anywhere any more with an expectation of privacy probably belongs in jail anyway,

The current Court is seen as leaning conservative, which currently seems to mean that they favor strong and broad government investigative powers. However, there also seems to be a thread running through the court that looks to legacy, thanks to the conscience of the Chief Justice. Therefore, it's not a certainty either way, but my judgement leans toward "no."
